title: Flight from Dallas to LA diverts to Tucson after passenger assaults others
text:
David Broseh (pictured) was arrested after a Southwest Airlines flight was forced to divert to Tucson, Arizona

A Southwest Airlines flight from Dallas to LA was forced to divert after a 'drunk' passenger allegedly assaulted fellow flyers.

The jet changed course and landed at Tucson International Airport in Arizona on Tuesday before unruly David Broseh was arrested, police say.

Officials said the 51-year-old, from Marrieta, Oklahoma, was intoxicated and assaulted passengers during the flight.

He was detained by Tucson Airport Authority police on arrival before being escorted to Pima County jail.

Jessie Butler, director of Communications and External Relations at the airport said: 'Whenever there could potentially be an issue with a passenger disturbance on an aircraft, our police are always notified and called and we have an on-staff 24/7 police department at the airport so they were called and they responded.'

Southwest Airlines said it is against airline policy to serve any more alcohol to people who appear impaired.

In a statement, the firm added: 'The flight landed safely at TUC and continued onward to LAX after the brief diversion.

'The safety of our customers and crew is always our top priority, so we appreciate the patience of our customers during the event.'

Butler said that witness statements were collected when the plane landed and Broseh was under arrest for two counts of assault and one of disorderly conduct.

Despite the diversion, the plane made its onward journey to LA from Tuscon after the arrest.
